title: SkyGreece airline leaves hundreds stranded as it to 'cease all operations'
text:
3k shares 19
View
comments
Hundreds of passengers have been left stranded abroad after a Greek airline has ceased all operations, following its launch in May.
SkyGreece which flew from Canada to various points in Europe, announced that due to economic instability in Greece, it can no longer provide a service.
The airline only owns one aircraft - a Boeing 767-300 ER, and leases another, an Airbus A330-200, that is based in New York.
SkyGreece Airlines' inaugural flight was only in May this year, and now they have stopped operations
A statement on the airline's website reads: 'SkyGreece Airlines would like to apologise to all of its passengers who have been affected as a result of the Company's current operational crisis.
'The founders, managers and employees of SkyGreece care deeply about their passengers and have been working around the clock to resolve the problem.

Share this article Share 3k shares 'Shortly after launching scheduled international service in May, SkyGreece suffered financial setbacks as a result of the Greek economic crisis.
'In spite of the resulting immediate and dramatic reduction in ticket sales, the Company's founders have worked tirelessly to maintain scheduled service. Unfortunately, as a result of recent technical issues, the company is now facing a system-wide multi-day delay and significant additional expenses.
'As a result, SkyGreece management regrets to announce that it must temporarily cease all operations. The Company expects to resume operations soon.
'Passengers should contact their travel agent to arrange for alternate travel and/or accommodations.'
Customers are stranded after SkyGreece confirmed operations were 'ceasing,' also confirmed by Toronto Airport where their sole owned plane flies out from
PASSENGERS' RIGHTS UNDER EUROPEAN LAW Passenger rights under EC Regulation No 261/2004: SkyGreece Airlines, its subsidiaries and affiliates make every effort to operate to their published schedules. There are occasions, however, where it is not possible to do so and a flight may be delayed or cancelled.
Should this happen, EC Regulation No 261/2004 provides passengers with specific rights. This law is applicable to all passengers departing from an airport within the EU and to all passengers travelling into an EU Member State on an EU carrier.
EC Regulation No. 261/2004 explains how to claim compensation, a refund or reimbursement under this law with respect to flights operated by SkyGreece Airlines S.A.
The Greek-based start-up, whose offices are in Athens, has only been running commercial flights for three months.
They operate flights out of Montreal, Toronto, New York JFK, Athens, Thessaloniki, Budapest and Zagreb
Yesterday three flights were cancelled from Toronto, while the second plane has been grounded at Pearson International Airport for the last two days.
A Facebook group has since been set up called SkyGreece Troubles, with around 700 people joining to air their grievances.
The Toronto Star reports that one passenger, Alex Repka, said he was forced to shell out extra cash last week when his flight back to Toronto from Budapest was cancelled.
'When I had arrived and walked to their counter, there was nobody there, just a sheet of paper stating the numbers that I could call to figure something out,' he said.
And speaking to CTV News , Bessie Broussalis says her elderly father is stranded in Greece after his return flight to Canada was cancelled.
'It is a big inconvenience -- there is a lot of stress involved,' the Quebec resident said.
'He is elderly. He is 74-years-old. He has medication that he will run out of.'
Worryingly, the owner of SkyWay Tours, Aris Sideratos, who uses the airline for passenger bookings, said that he has 'no clue of what's going to happen' in terms of getting customers home.
Toronto Pearson Airport saw SkyGreece cancel three flights this week before more decisive action was taken
